title-group.article-title: A new technology for recycling solder from waste printed circuit boards using ionic liquid

article-meta.aff: 1College of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai University, Shanghai, P.R. China
2Semiconductor Manufacturing International (Shanghai) Corporation, Shanghai, P.R. China

author-notes.corresp: Ping Zhu, College of environmental and chemical Engineering, Shanghai University, Shanghai, P.R. China Email: xhnzp@shu.edu.cn

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue: Waste electrical and electronic equipment

abstract.p: Waste printed circuit boards (WPCBs) contain lots of valuable resources together with plenty of hazardous materials, which are considered both an attractive secondary resource and an environmental contaminant. In this study, a new technology for the recovery of solder from WPCBs using an ionic liquid of 1-ethyl-3-methylimizadolium tetrafluoroborate ([EMIM+][BF4−]) as a heating medium was investigated. Experimental results indicate that the separation of solder from WPCBs is complete when WPCBs are heated at 240°C and [EMIM+][BF4−] is stirred at 150 rpm for 10 min. By observing the cross sections of WPCBs before and after treatment with the ionic liquid, it has been found that there is a initial delaminating phenomenon for WPCBs, which implies that [EMIM+][BF4−] can dissolve bromine epoxy resins of WPCBs to some extent. This clean and non-polluting technology offers a new way of recycling valuable materials from WPCBs and prevents the environmental pollution by WPCBs effectively.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In 2010, the United Nations (UN) Environment Programme reported that China produced 2,300,000 tons/year of electronic waste, similar to the quantity of electronic wastes of (3,000,000 tons/year) produced by the USA. The production of printed circuit boards (PCBs) is the base of the electronic industry as it is an essential part of almost all electrical and electronic equipment. According to NTInformation statistics, the global PCB output value reached $55 billion in 2010. In 2014, the global PCB output value will reach $69 billon with a compound annual growth of 9.5% (Lu, 2011). However, new technological innovation continues to accelerate the replacement of equipment, leading to a significant increase in waste PCBs (WPCBs) (Zhu and Gu, 2002).

A new environmental challenge is presented by WPCBs, which contain plenty of toxic substances, such as brominated ﬂame retardants (BFRs), polyvinyl chloride (PVC) plastic and heavy metals. If they are discarded randomly in the open environment or landﬁlled the leachate may inﬁltrate into groundwater and soil to cause serious environmental problems. Therefore, recycling of WPCBs is an important subject not only from the treatment for waste, but also from the recovery of valuable materials. WPCBs contain approximately 30% metals and 70% nonmetals. The typical metals in PCBs are copper (20%), iron (8%), tin (4%), nickel (2%), lead (2%), zinc (1%), silver (0.2%), gold (0.1%) and palladium (0.005%) (Gockmann, 1992). Meanwhile, the purity of precious metals in WPCBs is more than 10 times higher than that of rich-content minerals. Therefore, WPCBs are considered as an ‘urban mineral resource’. In addition, the nonmetal portions of PCBs consist of thermoset resins and reinforcing materials. They also can be reused as ﬁllers in composite materials (Gu et al., 2008, Kui et al., 2009).

Existing processes of recycling WPCBs include the pyrometallurgical method, the hydrometallurgical method, a mechanical-physical process, vacuum pyrolysis and a supercritical process (Guo et al., 2008; Kim et al., 2010; Kui et al., 2009; Li et al., 2007; Zhu et al. 2009). However, these methods are usually used to recycle bare PCBs. Less attention has been paid to the dismantling and recycling of PCB assemblies (PCBAs). A PCBA is a PCB mounted with electronic components (ECs), which are connected by solder (Duan et al., 2011). Therefore, the first step in dismantling a PCBA is to remove solder. Some researchers have studied other methods of removing solder, such as using an infrared heater or electric heating tube (Gao, 2007; Li et al., 2006; Wa et al., 2005), using a liquid as a heating medium (Gao, 2007; Huang et al., 2007; Zhong et al., 2008), using solder baths as a heating medium or using a chemical reagent (Frank, 2002; Hao et al., 2008; Haruta et al., 1991; Li et al., 2009; Zhou and Qiu, 2010). However, these technologies have some problems: how to dispose of the used hot ﬂuid, how to ensure the safety of the process, how to select suitable chemical reagents and so on (Duan et al., 2011).

In this study, ionic liquids of 1-ethyl-3- methylimizadolium tetrafluoroborate ([EMIM+][BF4−]) as a heating medium was used to recycle valuable solder from WPCBs. Ionic liquids are organic salts that are liquid at ambient temperatures and are composed of large organic cations, and small inorganic or organic anions, and have been accepted as a new green chemical revolution, which has excited both academia and the chemical industries. Ionic liquids can be considered as an alternative method of recycling WPCBs because of its outstanding properties: negligible vapor pressure, excellent thermal stability (<400°C) (Li, 2005), wide interval of hydrophilic–hydrophobic balance, good dissolution properties with many organic compounds (including polymers or cellulose) and low flammability (Aslanov et al., 2011; Kubisa et al., 2009; Seda et al., 2007). The objective of the research was to try to recover valuable solder by ionic liquid of [EMIM+][BF4−] and to establish a recovery technology to settle the problem of WPCBs.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: The WPCBs for this study were collected from the solid waste disposal center in Shanghai, China. WPCBs were computer motherboards (the content of precious metals is low and main content is copper), which were made from glass fiber reinforced bromine epoxy resin. The electronic components of the WPCBs were removed by manual operation and the WPCBs samples were broken into pieces (15–20cm2) before experimentation. The heating medium was [EMIM+][BF4−], which was synthesized in the laboratory by referring to the literature (Wang et al., 2011). The measurement of [EMIM+][BF4−] used here was carried out using the infrared spectrum with IFS 55 (Bruker, Fällanden, Zurich, Switzerland).

[EMIM+][BF4−] was put into a stainless steel cylinder 1 litre in size. The WPCB samples were put into the cylinder and submerged by [EMIM+][BF4−]. The ratio of solid to liquid for WPCBs to ionic liquid was 1:5. [EMIM+][BF4−] was agitated by the stirrer at a speed of 150 rpm. The heating of [EMIM+][BF4−] began at 25°C and the ramping rate was 5°Cmin-1. It was then maintained at at 240°C for 10 min. As a result, the molten solder was discharged from the stirring [EMIM+][BF4−] and fell to the bottom of the stainless steel cylinder. Finally, solder and baseplates were collected after the [EMIM+][BF4−] was cooled. Photographs of the WPCBs treated with [EMIM+][BF4−] and solder were taken using a digital camera. A metallographic microscope (EPLPHOT 300) was used to observe the initial delamination of WPCBs.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The performance of [EMIM+][BF4−] was determined by Fourier transform-infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) analysis. From Figure 1a it can be seen that the FT-IR spectrum of ionic liquid [EMIM+][BF4−] was in accordance with Zheng and Mo (2009). The FT-IR spectrum of [EMIM+][BF4−] used to recover solder from WPCBs is shown in Figure 1b. Comparison of the FT-IR spectra of Figure 1a and 1b found that the FT-IR spectrum of the used [EMIM+][BF4−] was comparable with that of baseline ionic liquid. This result indicates that the ionic liquid used to treat WPCBs was unchanged and can be reused to decrease cost.

caption.p: Fourier transform-infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) analysis of ionic liquid [EMIM+][BF4−].

sec.p: Generally, the melting point of solder used in PCBs is above 183°C. When the solder of WPCBs melted, the other components of remained solid. So, the separation of solder can be realized by a stirring process under well-controlled conditions. In this study, ionic liquid [EMI+][BF4−] was used as medium to heat WPCBs until the solder melted into a liquid state; it was the recycled from WPCBs by the stirring process to produce small centrifugal force. During the solder separation process there are three main forces acting on the molten solder, including centrifugal force, gravity force and surface conglutinate force (Zhou and Qiu, 2010). The stirring process is propitious to remove the molten solder from WPCBs, but the surface conglutinate force prevents the molten solder separating from WPCBs. In this work, the stirring process not only increased the collision probability between melting solders, but also produced a resultant force produced by both gravity and centrifugal force, which overcomes the surface conglutinate force to realize the separation of solder from WPCBs. As a result, the molten solder and [EMIM+][BF4−] were discharged from the stainless steel cylinder by the filtration, and the solid WPCBs were separated and remained inside the stainless steel cylinder.

In the study, the utilization of stirring separation for recovering the molten solder from WPCBs was very effective. At the same time, t[EMIM+][BF4−] temperature was also an important factor, which determined the degree of melting of solder. The higher the i[EMIM+][BF4−] temperature was, the lower the viscosity of the molten solder was. The low viscosity of the molten solder decreased ﬂow resistance, which was easily removed from WPCBs. Almost all solders were recovered from WPCBs when [EMIM+][BF4−] temperature was 240°C, but WPCBs were slightly damaged and there were not toxic substances produced in this process. From the point of view of saving energy, 240°Cwas the optimum temperature for separating solder from WPCBs. The illustrations of recovery solder and removing solder from WPCBs are shown in Figure 2 respectively. It could be seen that all solders were separated from the baseplates of WPCBs and that the copper foil was exposed to the surface of WPCBs (Figure 2a, b). The chemical properties of the recovered solder remained unchanged because ionic liquid did not react with metals. The recovered solder (Figure 2c) can be reused directly, and it can also be a good resource of lead and tin for reﬁning. Thus, the solder can be separated from WPCBs earlier, which is very important in the process of recovering metals from WPCBs.

caption.p: Photographs of waste printed circuit boards (PCBs) before (a) and after (b) treated by ionic liquid and solder (c).

sec.p: As shown in Figure 3a and b, the baseplate of WPCBs produced the initial delaminating phenomenon after treated by [EMIM+][BF4−]. Meanwhile, the initial delamination of WPBCs was also observed by metallographic microscope, as shown in Figure 4 a and b. It was inferred that adhesive epoxy resins between the PCBs layers dissolved into the [EMIM+][BF4−] solution, which will cause separation of the copper foil of WPCBs. Therefore, WPCBs treated by [EMIM+][BF4−] provides a new method for the reutilization of metals and nonmetals from WPCBs. [EMIM+][BF4−] used to dissolve the epoxy resin of WPCBs will be researched thoroughly in the future.

caption.p: Photographs of cross-section of waste printed circuit boards (PCBs) before (a) and after (b) treatment with ionic solution.
Metallographic photographs of untreated and treated waste printed circuit boards (WPCBs).
(a) Untreated WPCBs. (b) WPCBs treated by [EMIM+][BF4−] at 240°C.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A new process which does not have a negative impact on the environment was developed to recover solder from WPCBs. An ionic liquid [EMIM+][BF4−] was used as a heating medium to melt the solder of WPCBs and then the molten solder was recycled efficiently by stirring the [EMIM+][BF4−]. The results showed that the separation of solder from WPCBs was complete when WPCBs were heated at 240°C and the stirrer rotated at 150 rpm for 10 min. The results of FT-IR analysis indicated that [EMIM+][BF4−] did not change after treating WPCBs and, as such, it could be reused. The WPCBs were treated with [EMIM+][BF4−] to produce the delaminating phenomenon. In addition, [EMIM+][BF4−] dissolving of the epoxy resin of WPCBs will be investigated thoroughly in the future.
